column1: Thiamin is one of the B vitamins.
The B vitamins are a group of water-soluble vitamins that are part of many of the chemical reactions in the body.
The main role of carbohydrates is to provide energy for the body, especially the brain and nervous system Thiamin also plays a role in muscle contraction and conduction of nerve signals.

Thiamin is found in: - Enriched, fortified, and whole grain products such as bread, cereals, rice, pasta, and flour - Wheat germ - Beef liver and pork - Dried milk - Egg - Legumes and peas - Nuts and seeds Dairy products, fruits, and vegetables are not very high in thiamin in small amounts.
A lack of thiamin can cause weakness, fatigue, psychosis, and nerve damage.
Thiamin deficiency in the United States is most often seen in people who abuse alcohol (alcoholism).
The RDA for vitamins may be used as goals for each person.
